text.text: You should look at this chart about music genres.
In 2016, Spotify began publishing a chart of popular genres on its platform.
It gets interesting when you compare it to the 2023 data.
I’ve highlighted the genres that are not on the 2016 list, which set off a research project to uncover what happened.
I discovered a big idea, one that changed how I think about music.
This is going to take some explaining, so let’s first tackle some obvious trends in the data.
First, what genres are more popular today than in 2016?
In 2016, k-pop was the 283rd most-streamed genre.
Over the past 7 years, it’s ascended to the 17th most-streamed genre.
Incredibly, k-pop has more streams than R&B and EDM.
You’ve probably heard of Bad Bunny, the world’s most-streamed musician, three years running. Fittingly, reggaeton is the only other genre to exhibit a k-pop-like ascent.
Reggaeton’s ascent should be surprising. Today, Spotify users from North America and Europe represent a much smaller share of streams than in 2016.
Every year, Spotify is available in more countries. Spotify added South Korea in 2021. And India in 2019. Fittingly, you can see non-English genres begin to dominate in popularity.
Zooming into the top 25, nearly half of genres hail from Latin America, Africa, and Asia.
